title: Elderly Fall With Suspected Pelvic Fracture
scenarioIntro: A quiet hallway becomes the scene of a painful mystery: what starts as a simple lift assist quickly reveals deeper complexity. This case asks you to pause, observe, and think critically before moving forward.

dispatchNotes: 82 y/o female fell in hallway, can't get up
Reports hip pain and inability to move
Caller is daughter, unsure if patient hit her head
callInformation.crewNotes: BLS crew on scene; ALS 15 minutes out. Prepare for extrication support.

patientDemographics.name: Marjorie Ellison
patientDemographics.appearance: Pale, frail, and visibly uncomfortable; lying on her left side

patientPresentation: Marjorie lies on the hallway carpet, curled slightly, clutching her left hip. Her face is tense, and she winces with the slightest movement. She‚Äôs alert but nervous, answering quietly. *(üí°amber|This is where you pause. Take in the surroundings. Her position tells a story ‚Äî don‚Äôt rush past it.)*
incidentNarrative: The daughter reports hearing a 'thump' around 07:45. Found her mother on the ground complaining of hip pain. She didn‚Äôt see the fall. Patient was trying to make her way to the bathroom alone. No loss of consciousness reported.

opqrst.onset: Sudden ‚Äî during attempt to walk to bathroom

sampleHistory.signsAndSymptoms: Left hip pain, no head strike or dizziness reported
sampleHistory.eventsLeadingUp: Attempted to walk unassisted to the bathroom

physicalExam.generalAppearance: Thin, elderly female in mild distress, unable to reposition herself *(üí°amber|Frailty cues matter ‚Äî treat every repositioning as a potential harm point.)*
physicalExam.pelvis: Tender to palpation, minimal movement attempted *(üí°red|Suspect pelvic fracture when tenderness and immobility coexist ‚Äî always stabilize before movement.)*
physicalExam.extremities: Left leg appears shortened and externally rotated *(üí°red|Classic signs of pelvic or proximal femur injury ‚Äî don‚Äôt miss what‚Äôs staring at you.)*

firstSet.GCS: 15 *(üí°amber|A GCS of 15 doesn‚Äôt rule out internal injury ‚Äî stay alert for subtle deterioration.)*

secondSet.HR: 108 *(üí°amber|Even small increases in HR could signal pain, anxiety, or early compensation. Don‚Äôt ignore trends.)*

caseProgression:
If the crew recognizes signs of a pelvic fracture and limits movement, Marjorie remains stable, albeit in pain. Gentle handling and pelvic stabilization improve her comfort. *(üí°red|Notice what gets worse first ‚Äî that‚Äôs your early warning. Movement without support rapidly worsens pain and risk.)* According to the BLS PCS, spinal motion restriction is not indicated here, but pelvic binding falls under the trauma standard and should be considered.

If movement is attempted without stabilization or if lifting is done improperly, pain increases, and Marjorie becomes more anxious and tachycardic. Delays in transport or failure to identify the fracture worsen her status en route.
expectedTreatment: Primary goals include pain mitigation, pelvic stabilization, and safe extrication. Apply a pelvic binder per ALS PCS Trauma Standard if trained and indicated. Use a scoop stretcher or vacuum mattress to minimize movement. Do not delay transport for ALS arrival unless vital signs destabilize. Monitor for shock signs due to anticoagulation. *(üí°amber|Even if ALS is 15 minutes out, don‚Äôt freeze. BLS doesn‚Äôt mean Basic Thinking ‚Äî stabilize what you can and move thoughtfully.)*
vocationalLearningOutcomes: VLO 1: Perform complete patient assessments and integrate findings into care plans
VLO 3: Demonstrate knowledge of anatomy, pathophysiology, and pharmacology relevant to emergency care
VLO 5: Communicate clearly and effectively with patients, families, and healthcare professionals
teacherPoints: Recognizing pelvic fracture signs early can prevent worsening shock ‚Äî especially with anticoagulants.
Stabilization is more than equipment ‚Äî it's communication, planning, and minimizing risk.
Scene safety includes anticipating extrication paths in tight quarters.
This case reinforces the need to link physical signs with PCS-aligned interventions.
*(üí°amber|This is a call where thinking clearly buys more time than acting quickly. Teach that restraint and preparation are active skills.)*

title: Toddler Seizure at Daycare After Fever
scenarioIntro: Sometimes the quietest calls bring the most fear. A worried daycare worker calls 911 ‚Äî 'He just started shaking and won't wake up right!'

callInformation.location: Sunshine Valley Daycare, suburban residential area
dispatchNotes: Caller reports 2-year-old male child seizing and unresponsive
Child is now breathing but unresponsive
callInformation.crewNotes: Code 4 response, parents en route from work

patientDemographics.name: Leo Morrison
patientDemographics.appearance: Limp toddler lying on his side on a small nap mat, flushed cheeks, damp forehead

patientPresentation: Leo is semi-conscious, not responding to verbal stimuli but moans to painful stimuli. He has flushed skin and is febrile to the touch. His breathing is rapid but regular. There‚Äôs no sign of trauma, and he is postictal. *(üí°orange|This is where students often over-focus on the seizure ‚Äî but what‚Äôs the underlying cause?)*
incidentNarrative: The daycare worker reports Leo had been napping when he suddenly stiffened and began convulsing for about a minute. No incontinence noted. He has been 'under the weather' the last day or two but was active earlier in the morning. They took his temperature earlier today, and it was 38.5¬∞C.

opqrst.Time: Occurred approximately 5 minutes prior to your arrival

sampleHistory.Last Oral Intake: Crackers and juice at snack time (~11:00)
sampleHistory.Events Leading Up: Fever began yesterday, seizure started while napping

pastMedicalHistory: Generally healthy toddler, no seizure history

physicalExam.General: Postictal, flushed, semi-conscious *(üí°orange|Watch for postictal states in pediatrics‚Äîthey can mimic low GCS trauma but follow a very different course.)*
physicalExam.Head/Neck: No trauma, fontanelles flat, pupils equal/reactive
physicalExam.Chest: Breath sounds clear bilaterally, tachypneic *(üí°orange|Increased respiratory rate may be compensatory‚Äîalways correlate with temperature and SpO‚ÇÇ.)*

firstSet.Temp: 39.1¬∞C *(üí°orange|Febrile seizures often spike over 38.5¬∞C. Temp management is your cue to intervene.)*
firstSet.GCS: 9 (E2 V2 M5) *(üí°orange|Don't confuse low GCS post-seizure with head trauma‚Äîcontext is everything.)*

secondSet.GCS: 12 (E3 V3 M6) *(üí°green|Improving GCS is your cue that the postictal phase is resolving.)*

caseProgression.withProperTreatment: If Leo is assessed gently, kept cool, monitored, and fever is treated with antipyretic per protocol, his level of consciousness gradually improves. *(üí°green|Febrile seizures are frightening, but usually benign ‚Äî calm scene leadership is key.)*
caseProgression.withoutProperTreatment: If fever is not addressed, or if rough handling/agitation occurs, his condition may stagnate. He may vomit or worsen neurologically, and parents may arrive angry or panicked, increasing stress on scene.

expectedTreatment: Ensure scene safety, pediatric BLS assessment, monitor ABCs, take full history from caregivers. Expose and cool the child, remove excess clothing, and administer acetaminophen as per ALS PCS (PCP scope, febrile seizure directive). Transport in recovery position, monitor vitals. *(üí°green|Don‚Äôt wait for ALS ‚Äî if you can give the antipyretic, give it. Calm and steady always wins here.)*

teachersPoints: Students often freeze when pediatric seizures are mentioned. This case is about knowing what‚Äôs within your scope and not panicking. Look for reversible causes. Reassure caregivers. And most importantly ‚Äî treat the fever. Don‚Äôt forget how dangerous inaction is, even when the worst part seems 'over.'

selfReflectionPrompts.title: Diabetic Ketoacidosis in a Public Washroom
selfReflectionPrompts.scenarioIntro: The call comes in from a local shopping plaza ‚Äî a janitor reports a young adult unresponsive in a locked public washroom stall.

callInformation.location: Public washroom in a downtown shopping mall
dispatchNotes: Caller reports male unresponsive in locked stall
Unknown if drugs or medical issue
hazardsOrFlags: Public location with high foot traffic
callInformation.crewNotes: Bring suction and PPE. Prepare for altered LOC or environmental hazard.

patientDemographics.name: Tyler Ross
patientDemographics.appearance: Thin, pale, breathing rapidly with deep sighing breaths. Strong fruity odor present.

selfReflectionPrompts.patientPresentation: Tyler is found collapsed on the floor of the washroom stall, knees tucked in, barely responsive. His skin is warm and dry, and he appears dehydrated. A glucometer is clutched loosely in one hand. *(üí°yellow|This is where you pause ‚Äî smell that? That fruity breath matters.)*
selfReflectionPrompts.incidentNarrative: Security had to unlock the stall. Tyler was last seen by mall staff around noon acting confused. A janitor discovered him after noticing a strong acetone-like smell. No drugs or paraphernalia were found, but Tyler's backpack contains insulin pens.

sampleHistory.signsSymptoms: Confusion earlier in day, now unresponsive. Fruity breath, Kussmaul respirations.
sampleHistory.eventsLeading: May have missed insulin doses or had illness

medications: Insulin glargine (long-acting insulin, helps manage baseline glucose)

physicalExam.generalAppearance: Lethargic, barely responsive *(üí°yellow|This isn‚Äôt just ‚Äòtired‚Äô ‚Äî this is metabolic fatigue. Look for the patterns that tell you this is serious.)*
physicalExam.headNeck: No trauma noted *(üí°yellow|Rule out trauma fast but don‚Äôt anchor there ‚Äî this is medical until proven otherwise.)*
physicalExam.chest: Clear air entry, deep Kussmaul breaths *(üí°yellow|Those exaggerated sighs are the body trying to breathe off acid ‚Äî hear them, name them, act on them.)*
physicalExam.abdomen: Soft, mild tenderness on palpation *(üí°yellow|Tenderness without rigidity supports DKA, not intra-abdominal trauma.)*
physicalExam.extremities: No edema, cool peripheries *(üí°yellow|Peripheral perfusion tells you how bad the hypovolemia might be.)*

firstSet.BGL: 22.4 mmol/L *(üí°yellow|If you‚Äôre still hunting for drugs after reading this number, you‚Äôve missed the diagnosis.)*

secondSet.BGL: 22.1 mmol/L *(üí°yellow|Slight drop in GCS, rising HR, still acidotic. This is your cue ‚Äî intervene, escalate, monitor.)*

caseProgression.withProperTreatment: With early recognition and BGL testing, paramedics identify hyperglycemia and support airway/breathing. Patient remains hypoperfused but stable and GCS plateaus. ALS intercept improves outcome.
caseProgression.withoutProperTreatment: If glucose isn‚Äôt checked or fruity breath is dismissed, patient deteriorates into coma with worsening shock. Hypovolemia and acidosis compound without fluids.

selfReflectionPrompts.expectedTreatment: Position semi-Fowler's, initiate high-flow oxygen if patient shows signs of hypoxia or further GCS drop (per BLS PCS). Confirm hyperglycemia with BGL testing. Establish IV, monitor vitals. Request ALS for fluid resuscitation. Do not administer oral glucose. Protect airway.
selfReflectionPrompts.teachersPoints: If you smell ketones and see rapid breathing in a diabetic patient ‚Äî think DKA, not overdose. Don't waste time hunting for drugs if the history and vitals scream acidosis. Students often delay glucose checks ‚Äî make it part of your first 5 minutes.

selfReflectionPrompts.title: Overdose and Mental Health Crisis at a College Residence
selfReflectionPrompts.scenarioIntro: It‚Äôs late evening at a campus residence. A call comes in: a student is locked in their room, unresponsive, and a friend is panicking. You‚Äôre dispatched with minimal info ‚Äî and an uneasy feeling in your gut.

dispatchNotes: Caller reports patient locked in room, not responding
Roommate emotionally distressed and unable to provide clear history
callInformation.crewNotes: Campus security may meet you at entrance; be prepared for complex emotional context

patientDemographics.name: Jordan Reyes
patientDemographics.appearance: Lying on the bed, pale, slow to respond, visibly disoriented

selfReflectionPrompts.patientPresentation: Jordan is lying supine on the bed, blinking slowly and responding with slurred one-word answers. There‚Äôs a slight chemical odor in the room, empty pill bottles scattered nearby, and a nearby laptop with a partially written note. *(üí°orange|This is one of those scenes where emotional tone matters ‚Äî pause before you act.)*
selfReflectionPrompts.incidentNarrative: Jordan was found by their roommate after not attending a scheduled group meeting. Roommate states Jordan has been ‚Äúnot doing well lately‚Äù and may have taken ‚Äúsomething‚Äù earlier in the evening. They last saw Jordan around 17:00 and report they‚Äôve been withdrawn since a recent breakup.

opqrst.Provocation: Unclear, patient not coherent enough to answer
opqrst.Time: Roommate reports patient has been unresponsive since ~20:30

sampleHistory.SignsSymptoms: Confusion, slurred speech, mild respiratory depression
sampleHistory.PastMedicalHistory: Generalized anxiety disorder, recent suicidal ideation
sampleHistory.LastOralIntake: Ate dinner around 18:00, unsure if anything since
sampleHistory.EventsLeadingUp: Suspected overdose; evidence of pill bottles and note; emotionally volatile context

medications: Sertraline - SSRI, used for depression/anxiety; overdose can cause serotonin toxicity
Propranolol - Beta-blocker, used for anxiety and heart rate control; overdose may cause bradycardia/hypotension
selfReflectionPrompts.pastMedicalHistory: Generalized anxiety disorder; recent emotional stressor (relationship breakup)

physicalExam.generalAppearance: Lethargic, barely responsive *(üí°red|This isn‚Äôt just fatigue ‚Äî metabolic emergencies present with this kind of profound weakness. Ask yourself: does this match DKA or something else?)*
physicalExam.headNeck: No signs of trauma, pupils sluggish but equal *(üí°yellow|Pupils help you rule out neurological or toxic causes ‚Äî don‚Äôt skip them even in medical calls.)*
physicalExam.chest: Air entry clear bilaterally with deep, labored Kussmaul respirations *(üí°purple|Kussmaul = metabolic acidosis compensation. If you hear it, think DKA or salicylates.)*
physicalExam.abdomen: Soft, mildly tender, no guarding or rigidity *(üí°blue|Tenderness without peritonitis helps steer you away from surgical causes.)*
physicalExam.extremities: Cool peripheries, no edema, cap refill ~3s *(üí°green|Cap refill is a cheap and fast window into perfusion ‚Äî use it.)*

firstSet.ETCO‚ÇÇ: 18 mmHg *(üí°orange|Low ETCO‚ÇÇ in a breathing patient should scream 'acidosis' ‚Äî think DKA.)*
firstSet.BGL: 22.4 mmol/L *(üí°red|This value doesn‚Äôt just confirm hyperglycemia ‚Äî it helps confirm your differential.)*

secondSet.ETCO‚ÇÇ: 16 mmHg *(üí°orange|ETCO‚ÇÇ is falling ‚Äî this patient is breathing harder to compensate. Watch for fatigue.)*
secondSet.BGL: 22.1 mmol/L *(üí°red|No significant change ‚Äî but don‚Äôt wait for one. Time is tissue in DKA.)*

caseProgression.withProperTreatment: With high suspicion of overdose and close monitoring, students administer naloxone per protocol, reposition patient to support airway, and initiate rapid transport. Patient‚Äôs GCS improves modestly, and respiratory rate stabilizes. Roommate begins to cry and asks to ride along. Scene de-escalates with appropriate communication and empathy.
caseProgression.withoutProperTreatment: If the overdose is not recognized and airway is not managed, patient‚Äôs respiratory status continues to decline. ETCO‚ÇÇ rises, GCS drops to 9, and cyanosis becomes visible. Emotional scene becomes chaotic, roommate begins yelling, and the situation spirals into a high-risk, poorly managed transport.

selfReflectionPrompts.expectedTreatment: Students should assess mental status, rule out trauma, and consider toxidrome patterns. Oxygen should be titrated per BLS PCS (SpO‚ÇÇ <94%, target 92‚Äì96%). If opioid overdose is suspected based on scene and respiratory status, naloxone should be considered under ALS PCS. Verbal de-escalation and clear documentation of mental health risk are required. *(üí°teal|BLS doesn't mean Basic Thinking ‚Äî stabilize what you can, even if ALS is 10 minutes out.)*
selfReflectionPrompts.teachersPoints: This scenario isn‚Äôt about getting the perfect diagnosis ‚Äî it‚Äôs about reading the room. grsAnchors.title: Altered Behaviour in a Remote Campground
grsAnchors.scenarioIntro: A 36-year-old woman is acting bizarrely in a remote forest campground after a hike. Her partner says she was fine earlier, but now she‚Äôs confused, stumbling, and talking to people who aren‚Äôt there.

callInformation.location: Remote campsite, 4km down a forest trail
dispatchNotes: Caller reports woman acting erratically and talking to trees
Scene is remote; patient located near riverbank with firepit
Partner on scene; states she may have eaten wild berries
hazardsOrFlags: Difficult terrain, ATV or on-foot access only
callInformation.crewNotes: Expect 4km hike-in. ALS is 25+ minutes out, likely unavailable before extrication. Prepare for wilderness safety and prolonged on-scene time.

patientDemographics.name: Jillian Howe
patientDemographics.appearance: Flushed, alert but responding inappropriately; unkempt, wearing hiking clothes

grsAnchors.patientPresentation: Jillian is seated on a log beside the firepit, waving at the trees and mumbling incoherently. She occasionally bursts into laughter or shouts gibberish. *(üí°orange|This is where you pause and assess safety ‚Äî is she a threat to herself or others?)* Her pupils are dilated, and she occasionally scratches her arms. Her partner says she was normal an hour ago after a hike. She‚Äôs not recognizing familiar people or responding to questions appropriately.

physicalExam.general: Flushed, agitated, laughing randomly, pupils 6mm bilaterally *(üí°red|Large pupils and erratic behavior? Think stimulant or hallucinogen ‚Äî and scene safety comes first.)*
physicalExam.headAndNeck: No signs of trauma, responds inconsistently to voice *(üí°yellow|Always rule out trauma ‚Äî don‚Äôt anchor on tox alone in altered patients.)*
physicalExam.chest: Clear bilaterally, no retractions or abnormal sounds *(üí°purple|Just because lungs sound clear doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre oxygenating well ‚Äî monitor trends.)*
physicalExam.extremities: No swelling, tremors present, occasional muscle twitching *(üí°green|Twitching may hint at stimulant or serotonergic effects ‚Äî track for worsening signs.)*

firstSet.BGL: 6.9 mmol/L *(üí°blue|Normal sugar ‚Äî one cause of altered LOC ruled out. Keep checking others.)*

secondSet.ETCO2: 39 mmHg *(üí°orange|Normal ETCO‚ÇÇ now, but watch for sudden spikes or drops ‚Äî they can flag deterioration early.)*

caseProgression.withProperTreatment: Patient remains agitated but does not become violent. Vitals stay stable, and extrication proceeds safely. Ongoing monitoring and calm reassurance help keep the situation controlled. Good patient positioning and scene safety are maintained. ALS never arrives, and the crew must manage prolonged care on their own.
caseProgression.withoutProperTreatment: Without grounding communication and scene control, the patient may wander into the woods or become aggressive. If not monitored, she may seize or collapse. Partner becomes increasingly distressed and interferes with care. Vitals worsen with increasing HR and RR, and confusion deepens into unresponsiveness.

grsAnchors.expectedTreatment: Ensure scene safety first. Do not approach until safe. Begin with calm verbal reassurance, attempt to establish rapport. Assess for ingestion/toxin exposure (possibly hallucinogenic). Monitor vitals and mental status. Position patient safely, away from hazards. Prepare for prolonged extrication. Consider toxidrome support and early transport. *(üí°teal|BLS doesn‚Äôt mean Basic Thinking ‚Äî use everything you‚Äôve got to keep her safe.)* Document clearly, including behavior patterns, statements, and progression.
grsAnchors.teachersPoints: Not all altered LOC means stroke or seizure. Wilderness calls demand full-scene awareness, improvisation, and rapport under stress. Stay grounded ‚Äî this is what clinical judgment looks like when no one else is coming.
